label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, March 6, 1944
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, telling her of their move into a larger apartment, lamenting the lack of their Medway Plantation staff to help him, and describing the consequences of swimming in the water off the coast of Hawaii, which is currently covered in oil. Sidney continues in his letter to relay the news of the war that he read in Time magazine and deliver news of family members.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
March 6, 1944
Hey Hey Nuts,
Her[e] we are in our new aoartment and very fine
it is with the red rugs, redplush furniture and heavy dark
furniture. What could be more attractive in a tropical
climate. The heat farely exudes from every thing so that
little waves dance up and down and the morriors reflect the
thin haze that lies over the red assemble like a blanket of
smoke. Sunday was the moving day. Morris went to the office
and told me to start moving immediately. He returned at noon
and was am[a]zed that I had not moved evert[h]ing without the
help of a car or anything else. From then on until five thirty
I carried great loads up to the apartment, my back bowed with
their weight and my brow covered with xxxxx sweat. The Fuherer
sat in the apartment and gave me directions as to where to put
my burdens as he said that someone had to direct the work.
Finely everything was moved and I lay down on my bed with a sigh
of relief thinking that thoughX I was to tired to sleep I could
at least lieand rest. But no, the Fuherer had opened up all the
screens to let in the heavelny sunlight and the mosquitos not
realizing that it was only for the sunlight had poured in too.
When morning came I was pinpricked with little red dots so that
it looked as If I had contracted the plague or was half leopard.
But all in all the aprtment is very attractive. It is way up
in the air, has a porch off my bed room, another one off the
living room, great big windows, and is filled with sunshine,
breezes and soft air day and night. There is a wonderful
feeling of space after our little apartment, which though it 
was most attractive and far better furn[i]shed than this one now,[it]
seems to have been tiny and not worthy of our great personages.
This [one] neverless needs someone like Rose to lend a helping hand.
There are all these little things that she would seize upon and
dissappear for a morning shopping only to reappear with the
necseesitires that make the difference between an ordinary and
an attractive place. Of course there is the small matter of
bringing me coffee in bed, Of this I will not spea[k] for it seems
like a dream those days when Lizzie would ascend the steps and
deposit on my knee a tray groaning with eggs and bacon and I
would gorge and then roll over and fall asleep[,]almost ahead of you[,]
who woud be preten[d]ing that you were reading the morning paper
when I could hear the snore[s]ascending from behind this unworthy
screen.
AS A RESULT OF ALL THIS ACTIVITY [no reason for capitals
the machine just stuck] I missed my swim and sun bath, but did
not really care because lately the water has been so covered with
oil that it is not a pleasure to go in. The last time I bathed
the tar stuck to me in great globs and I had to take a sponge bath
with tuppontentine to regain my natural hue and not look like a
pickanany on theplanatati[o]n. It is especailly difficult to get it
off when it mixes in your hair. Then you have strange little
[End Page 1]
top xxxs knots that stand straight in the air and stiff curls that
look something like the ones you had in Windhoek when the coiffeur
finished with you there. There was a greet sight. Your hair
standing stiff and straight and your anger so great at the
indignity committed upon you that your face was absolutle y red
and all you could do was to splutter. My how I laugued.
Johnny Fell was going to come out and have a drink with me and
dinner the other evening but was unable to at the last moment.
However I hope he will wander out one of these days so we can talk
about the old days at palm beach and the life that was a life.
The thing that has given us the biggest laugh yet out here
is that in the last Time it spoke of what men had to do out on
the warring fronts. Movies are the great thing the article went
on, men will sit in the pouring rain wactching the screen, yes
life on the far flung outpost where life is lived in the raw such
as at ----- and it gave the name of this place with several others
This gave us all a big kick because we are so much safer than
we would be in New York that there is no comparison as you well
know. Now I read continually that the Germans are ginving you
hell and that I think you are in a certain amount of danger.
Nevertheless I really believe that the greatest darger lies in
to many dinner parties rather than too many bombs.
Armant has gone to stay with Fifi in San Mateo until
his ship sails. Olive will come from New Orleans and then
motor the car back. What they are doing with a car out there is
beyond me but there you are. They will undobtly have a wonderful
time and Edith will have to unlimber that old arm of hers and
play a little tennis provivding Armant is able to unlimber his
knee suffieciently enough to shuffle around the court. When he
arrives with us there will be the most distinughied gathering of
crooks that has ever been known. We will hoist a flag[,] Legendre
L[y]ing In Hospital above our door and all the world can pay five
cents and see us in our glass coffins, breathing but too tired to
move exxcept to eat and drink.
However do not get to full of yourself and think that
I am done andfinished because I will always beat you at
games[,]because everyone knows you are too fat to play.
Goodbye darling I wish we could be playing together now.
All my love.
Sidney Legendre
[End Page 2]
